title: The Quiver.format() test fails in some time zones

labels.name: status:confirmed
labels.description: Bug has been confirmed by the Streamlit team

body:
### Summary

The test case for `Quiver.format()` fails in some time zones.
It indicates the implementation is wrong or the test case is fragile.

### Steps to reproduce

Run the unit test `Quiver.test.ts` in a development env.

**Expected behavior:**

All tests pass anytime.

**Actual behavior:**

In some timezone, a test case for `Quiver.format()` with the following error:

```
 FAIL  src/lib/Quiver.test.ts
  ● Quiver › Public methods › format › date

    expect(received).toEqual(expected) // deep equality

    Expected: "1970-01-01"
    Received: "1969-12-31"

      358 |             numpy_type: "object",
      359 |           })
    > 360 |         ).toEqual("1970-01-01")
          |           ^
      361 |       })
      362 |
      363 |       test("datetime", () => {

      at Object.<anonymous> (src/lib/Quiver.test.ts:360:11)
```

Though I have not investigated it well, I think it fails if the time zone has a positive offset to GMT. For example,
* in JST (GMT+9), it fails
* in BST (GMT+1), it fails
* in GMT, it succeeds
* in GMT+1, it succeeds
* in EDT (GTM-4), it succeeds

The tested method may be the below which uses UTC conversion.
https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/e968e001984e07592c358911e1c484a802d2a81e/frontend/src/lib/Quiver.ts#L715

I don't know the original motivation of using `.utc()` so also don't know whether the implementation is correct or not, but anyway,
* If the implementation is wrong, it should be fixed.
* If the implementation is correct, the test case should be more robust so that it succeeds in any timezone.

### Is this a regression?

I don't know.

### Debug info

- Git commit: e968e001984e07592c358911e1c484a802d2a81e
- OS version: macOS Monterey 12.4
- Node version: v16.13.0
